descriptionProfile: We are Your Shot—National Geographic's photo community. Let's tell stories together. #YourShotPhotographer
We are Your Shot—National Geographic's photo community. Let's tell stories together.

posts.description:
Winter Boredom | Photograph by Angee Manns (@2bseenphotography)
.
“My son being incredibly bored inside during these cold winter days,” writes Your Shot photographer Angee Manns.
--
“I love how this frame feels like you’ve paused a moment in time Angee. I can feel how incredibly bored your son is. Keep documenting intimate and every day moments like this — you will have a beautiful portfolio of your family growing up over the years that will be cherished for generations.” — @natgeoyourshot associate photo editor David Y. Lee (@davidylee) #YourShotPhotographer

The Adopted | Photograph by Khant Zaw
.
Young boy with his little infant monkey at the Pho Kyar Elephant Camp in Myanmar. “It’s mother was killed by hunters,” reveals Your Shot photographer Khant Zaw.
--
“This is very touching and my daughter’s favorite image. The expression on the monkey and the comfort this infant needs from the close contact is visible here. Hunting the mom, leaving the infants is horrid and mentally scarring.” — Fine art/editorial photographer Robin Schwartz (@robin_schwartz) #YourShotPhotographer

Top Shot: Caught in the Net | Photograph by Qua Tan Nguyen
.
Your Shot photographer Qua Tan Nguyen captured this image of a fisherman checking his net while fishing on the Thu Bon River. The river is located near Hoi An, a city in Vietnam whose name translates to "peaceful meeting place."
--
Top Shot features the photo with the most votes from the previous day’s Daily Dozen, 12 photos chosen by the Your Shot editors from thousands of recent uploads. Our community votes for their favorite photo from the selection, and the Top Shot is showcased on the @natgeoyourshot Instagram account. #YourShotPhotographer

My Daughter | Photograph by Terra Fondriest (@terrafondriest)
.
“My daughter and I were driving down a gravel road and we got a flat tire,” writes Your Shot photographer Terra Fondriest. “She wanted to help, so I asked her to loosen the lug nuts. She realized it was a little harder than she thought, but definitely put all her strength into it.”
--
“Is it me or can I actually smell the wet autumn day in this photograph? Way to capture that element of misadventure. It happens to be the moments you often remember most: learning to fix a flat for the first time often trumps the gold awaiting at the end of the rainbow. Beautifully crafted image.” — Adventure photographer and filmmaker Andy Mann (@andy_mann) #YourShotPhotographer

My Sister | Photograph by Eastlyn Bright Tolle (@eastlyn_)
.
“A few weeks ago, I invited my sister Mackenzie (pictured) to join me and my husband on a camping trip to Shenandoah National Park,” writes Your Shot photographer Eastlyn Bright Tolle. “We woke up before dawn and climbed up over the boulders to the summit of Bearfence Mountain. The wind was harsh and cold, but the beauty of its wild movement complemented not only our eccentric artisan hearts, but life’s perfect symmetry. It’s in these moments, that I feel most alive.”
--
“This is such a nice portrait. I love how the mood just feels so calm; you captured that well. The hair blowing in the wind covers up just part of her face and leaves some mystery to the frame. This was an excellent moment in time to capture with a photograph. Nice work.” — @natgeoyourshot associate photo editor Matt Adams (@themattadams) #YourShotPhotographer

Top Shot: Ready for Take Off | Photograph by Marc Hoberman (@hobermanbooks)
.
Your Shot photographer Marc Hoberman captured this image of a vulture taking flight at Kruger National Park, South Africa. “Vultures are really fascinating birds. I love how this is photographed from a side angle with the feathers making a nice natural frame around the birds head,” writes @natgeoyourshot associate photo editor Matt Adams (@themattadams). “There’s some really nice details to view in this image as well. Whether it’s the wrinkles in the birds skin or ruffled edges of the feathers. Nice work being quick to capture this moment as the vulture takes flight.”
--
Top Shot features the photo with the most votes from the previous day’s Daily Dozen, 12 photos chosen by the Your Shot editors from thousands of recent uploads. Our community votes for their favorite photo from the selection, and the Top Shot is showcased on the @natgeoyourshot Instagram account. #YourShotPhotographer

Curious Cubs | Photograph by Ryan Green (@ryanxgreen)
.
A trio of curious hyena cubs approached Your Shot photographer Ryan Green's remote triggered camera in the Mombo concession of the Okavango Delta.
--
Today we’re featuring @natgeoyourshot photographs selected for @natgeo March’s “Photo of the Day.” To see more, go to natgeo.com/pod. #YourShotPhotographer

Clear Waters Ahead | Photograph by Gaby Barathieu (@gaby_barathieu_photography)
.
Dolphins swim in the waters off Mayotte, an archipelago in-between Madagascar and the coast of Mozambique in this over-under image.
--
Today we’re featuring @natgeoyourshot photographs selected for @natgeo March’s “Photo of the Day.” To see more, go to natgeo.com/pod. #YourShotPhotographer

Starfish, Star Bright | Photograph by Vadim Balakin (@vadimbalakin)
.
Starfish are lit by a stunning sky at Indian Beach, Oregon. This photo was submitted to @natgeoyourshot “Saving Our Oceans” assignment — curated by @natgeo photographer Brian Skerry (@brianskerry) and Senior Photo Editor Kathy Moran — which celebrated the power and wonder of our oceans.
--
Today we’re featuring @natgeoyourshot photographs selected for @natgeo March’s “Photo of the Day.” To see more, go to natgeo.com/pod. #YourShotPhotographer

[ #TellYourPollutionStory ]
Ganges River Pollution | Photograph by Sutapa Roy
.
“The main causes of water pollution in the Ganges River are the increase in population density, various human activities (like washing clothes and bathing of animals), and dumping of harmful industrial waste,” writes #YourShotPhotographer Sutapa Roy. “More than 420 million people rely on the river for food, water, bathing, and agriculture. The Ganges River pollution is getting seriously bad, and something needs to be done now.”
--
This Earth Day 2017, the focus is on environmental and climate literacy. We know that whether you’re 5 years old or 50, a powerful picture can grab your attention and help you understand the reality of threats to our environment. 9 million people die from pollution-related disease every year. It is the 3rd largest cause of death in the world with 92% of those deaths occurring in low- and middle-income countries. But pollution knows no borders, and travels the globe posing a major environmental health threat for the rich and poor alike.
.
@natgeoyourshot has partnered with @PureEarthNow — a unique environmental NGO that cleans up extremely polluted communities around the world. Pure Earth educates parents on the dangers of toxic waste in their midst, how to protect themselves and their children from exposure, and trains and hires them to conduct the actual cleanups. Join our Earth Day movement by sharing your photos and stories using the #TellYourPollutionStory hashtag to raise awareness about the #toxic pollution in air, water & soil around you. Together #WeCanFightPollution!
